description.narrative: Scaling-up of Glacier Lake Outburst Flood (GLOF) Risk Reduction in Northern Pakistan

activity-description.narrative: Reduce the risk of flash floods from glacial lake outbursts in high risk areas
Reduce the risk of flash floods from glacial lake outbursts in high risk areas
Reduce the risk of flash floods from glacial lake outbursts in high risk areas
Reduce the risk of flash floods from glacial lake outbursts in high risk areas
Reduce the risk of flash floods from glacial lake outbursts in high risk areas

description.narrative: seat of a second-order administrative division

activity-description.narrative: Reducing risk of flash floods in response to Glacial Melt

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).

description.narrative: 1.1: Strengthened institutional and regulatory systems for climate-responsive planning and development. [Scale: 1= Not adequately (up to 25%); 2= Very partially (26%-50%); 3= Partially (51%-75%); 4= Largely (75%-100%)] 1.2: Number of policies introduced to address GLOF risks or adjusted to incorporate GLOF risks. 2.1: Number of vulnerable households in KP and GB covered by a GLOF early warning system. 2.2: Number of Community-based organisations trained in the operation and maintenance of the EWS. 2.3: Number of physical assets constructed to withstand the effects of GLOF events. 2.4. Number of small-scale community driven initiatives financed through CBDRM funds

comment.narrative: 1.1: Scale 1 (National, provincial and local disaster management institutions and development planners are unable to design, finance and analyze GLOF risk reduction measures on the basis of reliable, comprehensive information.) 1.2: 2 (Only 2 comprehensive disaster management guidelines exist for the KP and GB regions.) 2.1: 0 (Vulnerable households are not able to receive and react to GLOF early warning messages.) 2.2: 2 ( 2 GLOF early warning system for KP and GB in place) 2.3: 0 (No physical structures in place to withstand the effect of GLOF events.) 2.4. 0 (No financial capacity of local communities to prepare and respond to GLOF events)

1.1: Scale 2 [By the end of Year 3, 100% of the national and 90% of district and community authorities in the KP and GB regions are able to prioritise and plan measures to minimise potential losses from GLOFs]. 1.2: 3 [Number of policies introduced to address GLOF risks or adjusted to incorporate GLOF risks]. 2.1: 696,342 people: 348,171 men, 348,171 women [Planned for end of project]. 2.2: 24 [By the end of the project, at least 24 CBOs are trained in the operation and maintenance of the EWS and ensure its continued functionality]. 2.3: 250 [By the end of the project, at least 250 targeted engineering structures have been established to withstand the effects of GLOF events on livelihood assets]. 2.4: 01 [By the end of the project, at least 01 community driven initiative in each of the 24 target valleys, is financed through CBDRM funds].

1.1: Scale 2 [To strengthen institutional capacity, Strengthening of District Emergency Response Cells (DERC); Procurement of emergency preparedness and response equipment and supplies (15 Districts of KP and GB) having USD 400,000 cost procured and handed over to the Provincial Governments. further to share learining and experince , GB Government officials visited to KP and KP Government officials visited to GB. further more, training on Face form also conducted to strength the organizational learning].
1.2: 0 [No progress made yet].
2.1: 0 [Under GLOF-II Project, initial assessments were carried out to identify potential valleys in 10 Districts of GB and 5 Districts of KP (E01- Progress Reports 2 &3). A team of officers from GLOF-II and government line departments, constituting P&DD, PDMAs, DDMA, Water Management Department, Forest Department, Agri. Dept, EPA, carried out ground truthing and field assessments, based on the report EWS sites will be finalized. However, due to surging of Shishper Glacier and formation of glacial lake at Hassan Abad, upper Hunza, GBDMA and district administration requested GLOF-II project to provide support in installation of EWS and EWS installed].
2.2: 0 [Under the project community meetings , awareness raising campaign, coordination workshop carried out and sensitized community members about the GLOF affectes on their lives. Through these series of meetings communities were engaged in different activities i.e glacier grafting, tree plantation and glacier cleaning campaign. Due to delays in implementation arrangements CBOs have not been formed]. 2.3: 0 [Initial assessment of vulnerable valleys has been done. After PSC endorsement proposed infrastructure activities will be carried out].
2.4: 0 [A consultant will be engaged on IC (Individual Contract) to develop guidelines for functioning of community based revolving funds. ToR is developed and submitted to NPD GLOF-II/ Secretary MoCC for approval].

1.1: Scale 4 [ By the end of Year 3, 100% of the national and 90% of district and community authorities in the KP and GB regions are able to prioritize and plan measures to minimize potential losses from GLOFs] 1.2. 4 [Number of policies introduced to address GLOF risks or adjusted to incorporate GLOF risks] 2.1: 696,342 people [348,171 men, 348,171 women [Planned for end of project]. 2.2: 24 [By the end of the project, at least 24 CBOs are trained in the operation and maintenance of the EWS and ensure its continued functionality]. 2.3: 250 [By the end of the project, at least 250 targeted engineering structures have been established to withstand the effects of GLOF events on livelihood assets]. 2.4: 01 [By the end of the project, at least 01 community driven initiative in each of the 24 target valleys, is financed through CBDRM funds].

1.1: Scale 3 [The project strengthened provincial line departments through experts and technical assistance in GIS mapping, conducting HVRAs and ground-truthing. Climate change cells have been established at national and sub-national level. Initial assessments (Baseline assessment, KAP studies, HVRA etc.) have been carried out. The project helped strengthen the District Emergency Response Cells (DERC) through procurement and provision of emergency and response equipment valued at USD 700,000 to the Disaster Management Authorities in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa and Gilgit-Baltistan (GBDMA and KPDMA). Components through UNDP support and GOP are on track, however, some activities impacted by COVID]
1.2: 0 [Guidelines and SOPs have been drafted for establishing CBDRMCs Revolving Funds, that will ultimately feed into the developmental plans at provincial and national level to incorporate GLOF risks. CCA action plan for GB has been initiated and is in progress whereas the same process for KP will be initiated in first quarter of 2021]
2.1: 0 [No Early Warning system has been installed yet. Partial procurement of equipment initiated, the procurement and installation of the remaining EWS equipment will be carried out in 2021]
2.2: 0 [12 CBOs (5 in KP and 7 in GB) have been established. Under the project, a series of community meetings, awareness raising campaigns, coordination workshops were conducted to sensitize communities and key stakeholders about the impact of GLOFs. 7 CBOs have had preliminary trainings on the operation and maintenance of EWS. Formal training to CBOs on EWS O&M will be provided once EWS is installed and functional]
2.3: 0 [The groundwork (site selection, design and layout, BoQs) for physical assets has been completed. Construction of most of the infrastructural activities could not be initiated due to COVID-19 restrictions and later on extreme weather conditions, however contracts have been issued against 13 irrigation channels in KP]
2.4: 0 [Guidelines were developed to finance the targeted communities in GB and KP, however, the project was later informed that the activity cannot be implemented as on-granting was not allowed under UNDPs accreditation status with the donor]

1.1: Scale 4 [By the end of Year 3, 100% of the national and 90% of district and community authorities in the KP and GB regions are able to prioritize and plan measures to minimize potential losses from GLOFs] 1.2. 4 [By the end of the project, number of policies introduced to address GLOF risks or adjusted to incorporate GLOF risks] 2.1: 696,342 people [348,171 men, 348,171 women [Planned for end of project]. 2.2: 24 [By the end of the project, at least 24 CBOs are trained in the operation and maintenance of the EWS and ensure its continued functionality]. 2.3: 250 [By the end of the project, at least 250 targeted engineering structures have been established to withstand the effects of GLOF events on livelihood assets]. 2.4: 01 [By the end of the project, at least 01 community driven initiative in each of the 24 target valleys, is financed through CBDRM funds].

1.1: Scale 3 [The strengthening of the institutions and departments both at Federal and Provincial level was done through trainings, workshops, capacity building for human resource, disaster risk reduction and disaster risk management. In 2021, 51 trainings were organized (community and stakeholders) in which 1609 participants attended (1080 men and 529 women), 71 community mobilization sessions with 2169 participants (1598 men and 571 women); 43 mock drills with 2138 participants (1395 men and 743 women) were conducted.] 1.2: 02 [This is Year 04 of the project with an extension until January 2024. The project has so far provided support and inputs for drafting of Climate Change Adaptation Action Plans for GB and KP. These will pave way for devising policy interventions for implementation of Climate Change Policy and Action Plans. The policies to be adopted to address the GLOF risks is linked to the institutional and regulatory systems for climate-responsive planning and development.]. 2.1: 0 [The mapping of households and beneficiaries is available with project for target valleys, Once the EWS is installed, all will benefit from installed EWS.] 2.2: 0 [In all 24 valleys, Community Based Disaster Risk Management Committees (CBDRMCs) have been established. The mandate of these Committees is to implement and safeguard project interventions, specifically focusing on sustainability after project completion. The EWS will be installed in 2022 after which formal training for Operations and Maintenance of EWS to these CBDRMCs will be provided]. 2.3: 28 [In 2021, the GIS mapping and HVRA studies for all 24 project valleys have been completed. 28 engineering structures (irrigation channels) have been completed in 2021 and remaining are aligned for construction in 2022.] 2.4: 0 [Revolving Fund activity is an on-granting activity and formal approval is awaited from GCF on revoking of this activity from project scope].

1.1: Scale 4 [By the end of 2022, 100% (MOCC and PMD) of the national and 100% of district authorities (P&DD, Forest Department, Irrigation department, OFWM, EPA etc.) and communities in KP and GB will be able to prioritize and plan measures to minimize potential losses from GLOFs through capacity building for EWS operation and maintenance and for project interventions] 1.2: 03 [By the end of 2022 at least 03 guidelines/strategy/policy (01 National Policy and 02 Provincial CCAP) have been established/adopted by the Government to address or incorporate GLOF risk reduction] 2.1: 696,342 people [348,171 men, 348,171 women [Planned for end of project]. 2.2: 24 [By the end of 2022, at least 24 CBOs would be trained in the operation and maintenance of the EWS and ensure its continued functionality] 2.3: 250 [By the end of 2022, at least 250 targeted engineering structures have been established to withstand the effects of GLOF events on livelihood assets]. 2.4: 0 [Revolving Fund activity is an on-granting activity and formal approval is awaited from GCF on revoking of this activity from project scope].
